title-group.article-title: Neonatal Stroke and Progressive Leukoencephalopathy in a Child With an ACTA2 Mutation

article-meta.aff: 1Center for Pediatric Neurology, Neurological Institute, Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, OH, USA
2Cole Eye Institute, Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, OH, USA
3Radiology Institute, Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, OH, USA
4Pediatric Cardiology, Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, OH, USA
5Genomic Medicine Institute, Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, OH, USA

author-notes.corresp: Neil R. Friedman, MBChB, Center for Pediatric Neurology/Desk S60, Neurological Institute, Cleveland Clinic, 9500 Euclid Avenue, Cleveland, OH 44195. Email: friedmn@ccf.org

abstract.p: Mutations in the smooth muscle–specific isoform of α-actin (ACTA2) cause vascular smooth muscle dysfunction leading to aortic aneurysm and moyamoya syndrome. A unique R179H mutation in ACTA2 has been reported to result in widespread smooth muscle dysfunction affecting vascular and extravascular smooth muscles. We report a 7-year-old girl with an ACTA2 R179H mutation manifesting with neonatal seizures due to multifocal infarcts, asymmetric motor deficits, global developmental delay, spasticity, congenital bilateral mydriasis, and a large patent ductus arteriosus. Serial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain over 7 years showed diffuse supratentorial white matter abnormalities consistent with a progressive leukoencephalopathy. Magnetic resonance angiography of the cerebral vessels showed stenosis in the terminal portion of the bilateral internal carotid arteries with fusiform dilation of the proximal segment. Neonatal onset of neurologic symptoms in ACTA2 mutations has not been previously reported. R179H mutation in ACTA2 represents the severe end of the disease spectrum.

body.p: Mutations in the smooth muscle–specific isoform of α-actin (ACTA2), a gene that encodes for a major contractile protein in vascular smooth muscle, typically manifest as aneurysms in the aorta and moyamoya syndrome.1 Recently, a novel de novo mutation in ACTA2 (p.R179H) has been linked to diffuse smooth muscle dysfunction with multisystem abnormalities.2 The spectrum of neurologic manifestations in this newly described entity is largely unknown. Neurologic manifestations occurring in the newborn period have not been previously described.

We report a 7-year-old girl with symptomatic neonatal seizures and asymmetric motor deficits due to multifocal infarcts, spasticity, and global developmental delay with progressive diffuse leukoencephalopathy. The presence of congenital bilateral mydriasis and large patent ductus arteriosus led to the diagnosis of an ACTA2 gene mutation.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: This 7-year-old girl was born at term gestation by cesarean section for fetal distress. She weighed 3500 g at birth. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. On day 2 of life, she developed right arm clonic seizures. Physical examination showed a lethargic newborn with bilateral mydriasis appearing as “dilated and non reactive pupils,” and hypertonia in the right upper and both lower extremities. Reflexes were initially subdued but subsequently became hyperactive with extensor plantar responses. Primitive reflexes were normal but her Moro response was incomplete. Head circumference was normal at 35 cm. No dysmorphic features were present. A comprehensive ophthalmologic evaluation confirmed bilateral iris abnormalities that simulated partial aniridia. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed multiple foci of acute infarction within the periventricular white matter and splenium of the corpus callosum, with associated minimal petechial hemorrhages (Figure 1). On day 3 of life, she developed congestive heart failure due to an unusually large, window-like patent ductus arteriosus, which was surgically repaired at 6 weeks of age. Intraoperatively, the anomaly was found to be an enormous “window” connecting the pulmonary artery bifurcation and proximal left pulmonary artery to the underside of the aortic arch, aortic isthmus, and upper descending aorta. On transecting the window under cardiopulmonary bypass, the connection was clearly of ductal tissue, suggesting that this was a huge ductal communication with no-length extending into the aortic arch and upper descending aorta. Following surgical repair, her cardiac function remained stable.

caption.p: Serial brain magnetic resonance imaging studies show progressive white matter abnormalities in the supratentorial regions. T1 weighted images at 10 days of age show abnormal hyperintense signals in the periventricular and deep white matter. Follow up images at 9 months (T2-weighted images) and 7 years of age (T2-weighted and fluid attenuated inversion recovery images) show marked increase in the signal abnormalities in the same region; also note cystic changes in the periventricular white matter.

sec.p: On serial follow-up visits until 7 years of age, she had normal physical growth, acquired microcephaly, global developmental delay, and asymmetric spastic quadriparesis with relative sparing of the left arm. She had no loss of acquired skills. She was treated with levetiracetam for seizure recurrence at 3 years of age. Follow-up brain MRI at ages 9 months, 3.5 years, and 7 years showed progressively increasing diffuse supratentorial white matter abnormalities, with mild dilation of the ventricles, and marked hyperintensity on T2-and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery images (Figure 1). Chiari I malformation with tonsillar descent of 6 mm was also noted. Spine imaging revealed no syringomyelia or cord tethering. Her eye findings were stable on follow-up with myopia of 3 diopters in each eye.

Given the progressive white matter abnormalities on early brain imaging, evaluation of causes for leukoencephalopathy was performed. Extensive biochemical and genetic workup for white matter disorders was negative. Following recent reports of ACTA2 mutations with iris, cardiac, and neurologic manifestations,2 sequencing of the ACTA2 gene was performed. This showed a pathogenic c.536G>A mutation in exon 6, confirming the genetic etiology for the syndrome. Magnetic resonance angiography of the cerebral vessels showed severe stenosis of the terminal portions of the bilateral internal carotid arteries, with dilation of the proximal cavernous-to-supraclinoid segment of the internal carotid arteries (Figure 2). Magnetic resonance angiography of the aorta showed no evidence of aneurysm. She had mildly delayed gastric emptying, and problems with chronic constipation requiring laxatives. No hypotonia of the bladder or dilation of the ureters was noted.

caption.p: Magnetic resonance angiography of the brain show striking diffuse intracerebral vascular disease characterized by ectasia of the large vessels, including the internal carotid and vertebral arteries along with abrupt supraclinoid narrowing with multiple foci of beading, and fusiform aneurysmal dilation of peripheral branches of both the carotid and vertebra-basilar arteries.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: ACTA2 is a highly conserved gene encoding for a smooth muscle cell isoform of α-actin, a major contractile protein in vascular smooth muscle cell. Mutations in ACTA2 alter the structure and assembly of actin filaments of vascular smooth muscle cell, leading to weakened vessel walls—a state of “vasculomyopathy.” The role of ACTA2 in vasculopathy was first reported in a study of families with thoracic aortic aneurysms.1 Later, early-onset coronary artery disease and strokes were also reported confirming ACTA2 mutations as a risk factor for a more widespread systemic vasculopathy.3 Recently, a report of 5 patients with a specific mutation in ACTA2 (c.536G>A) resulting in a R179H change was found to be associated with multisystem abnormalities. These patients had congenital mydriasis, patent ductus arteriosus, moyamoya syndrome, diffuse leukoencephalopathy, variable involvement of the pulmonary alveoli, and gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts suggesting more widespread dysfunction of smooth muscle in the vascular and extravascular systems.2 One other reported patient with the same mutation had only moyamoya syndrome without any other systemic features.4 Our patient had this unique mutation and had systemic and neurologic manifestations. Neonatal onset of neurologic symptoms as noted in our patient has not been previously described in this disorder.

The complete clinical spectrum of neurologic manifestations in ACTA2 R179H mutation is not well described. From the limited description of 5 patients in the medical literature, most have had transient neurologic deficits suggesting a stroke-like presentation, with the youngest age of onset being 2 years. Other manifestations include headache, tinnitus, hyperactivity, inattention, motor and language delay, and paraplegia due to spinal cord ischemia.2,5–7 Our patient presented with seizures, abnormal tone, and asymmetric motor deficits in the early neonatal period. Brain MRI shortly after birth showed features of multifocal ischemic brain injury in the bilateral periventricular region and evidence of a few petechial hemorrhages. Serial brain imaging showed increasing diffuse white matter abnormalities predominantly affecting the periventricular and deep white matter bilaterally, consistent with a progressive leukoencephalopathy. The white matter abnormalities in our patient were not typical for global hypoxic ischemic injury of a term infant and were remarkably similar in appearance to an earlier report of a patient with the same ACTA2 mutation.2 We believe that the brain lesions in our patient are secondary to the R179H mutation in ACTA2 and represent the severe end of the spectrum of this disease. Among ACTA2 mutations, the R179H mutation is considered the most severe in terms of both the degree and extent of systemic involvement. Some patients have been noted with symptomatic alveolar dysgenesis and hypomotility at birth.2 Another recent case report described fetal megacystis and gastrointestinal prune belly sequence along with other multisystem abnormalities.8 Findings in our patient suggest that neurologic manifestations can occur as early as the newborn period and possibly even in utero. The apparent nonprogressive clinical course in our patient probably reflects the very slow progression of the disease after a severe acute injury in early life.

The cerebrovascular abnormalities associated with the R179H ACTA2 mutation appear to be distinctly different from “moyamoya disease.” Almost all reported patients have had fusiform dilation of the cavernous-to-clinoid segment of the internal carotid artery, with stenosis or occlusion of the terminal portion of the internal carotid arteries. The stenotic segment often extends to the origin of anterior and middle cerebral arteries. Focal dilation of the internal carotid artery is not a typical finding in childhood “moyamoya disease.”9 We consider that such focal dilation may be a clue to the diagnosis of this rare genetic disorder. Detailed description of cerebral vasculature is not available in patients with other ACTA2 mutations to postulate whether this finding is universal in all ACTA2 mutations.3 Focal aneurysmal dilations occur as a result of weakened vessel wall from altered structural protein, and focal stenosis as a result of increased proliferation of smooth muscle cells in the intima and media of the arteries. These effects appear to be site-specific variably affecting different segments of the internal carotid arteries—stenosis in the distal segment and dilation in the proximal segment. The reason for such selective effects remains to be determined. It is uncertain whether our patient had moyamoya-type vasculopathy at birth, as vascular imaging was not performed until later on in life.

In conclusion, we report a child with an ACTA2 R179H mutation presenting with neurologic manifestations in the newborn period. Associated systemic manifestations, specifically congenital bilateral mydriasis and large patent ductus arteriosus, serve as key diagnostic clues to this rare disorder. Recognition of this disorder is critical to aid early recognition and management of systemic and cerebral vascular complications.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The work for this report was done at the Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, Ohio.

fn.label: Author Contributions
fn.p: All authors provided substantial contributions to conception, acquisition and interpretation of data. ANVM drafted the article and other authors revised it critically for important intellectual content. All authors approved the final version of the manuscript.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Ethical Approval
fn.p: This descriptive single case report does not require institutional review board/ethic committee approval. Parents of the patient provided informed consent to publish the report.
